translated: The Great Analysis🔽The chapter on training rules🔽The sub-chapter on pillars
The training rule on leaning on the hip

original: Tena samayena buddho bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: tena samayena buddhaḥ bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,

original: Tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyā bhikkhū pallatthikāya antaraghare nisīdanti …pe….
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena chabbaggiyāḥ bhikkhū pallatthikāya antaraghare nisīdanti pe
translated: the monks from the group of six were leaning on their hips while sitting in inhabited areas. …

analyzed: na pallatthikāya antaraghare nisīdissāmi iti sikkhā karaṇīyā ati
translated: “‘I will not lean on my hip while sitting in inhabited areas,’ this is how you should train.”
One should not lean on one’s hip while sitting in an inhabited area.

original: Yo anādariyaṁ paṭicca hatthapallatthikāya vā dussapallatthikāya vā antaraghare nisīdati, āpatti dukkaṭassa.
analyzed: yaḥ anādariyam paṭicca hattha pallatthikāya vā dussa pallatthikāya vā antaraghare nisīdati āpatti dukkaṭassa
translated: If a monk, out of disrespect, leans on his hip or on a cloth while sitting in an inhabited area, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.

analyzed: anāpatti  a san cit ca  assatiyā
translated: There is no offense🔽if it is unintentional,
if he is not thinking,🔽if he does not know,
if he is sick,🔽if he is traveling,🔽if there is a danger,
if he is the first offender.
